posts.name: Chris (Mentor|5032)
posts.cooked:
Good afternoon

We are trying to find a way to connect to our robot using the 6 Ghz band in the new VH109 radio.

We only have one VH109 and cant get another until next September.

I did some research and understand the whole Robot VH190 does not broadcast an AP issue.

So I purchased this router https://www.amazon.ca/dp/B0BN1FWVF3?ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_fed_asin_title

and have been trying to get the robot to connect to it.

Our team number is 5032.

In the Router LAN settings - I have the router set up as 10.50.32.6 Subnet 255.255.255.0 DHCP server off.   It is in router mode not AP mode. The WAN is not connected to anything.

In the wifi setting, I have 6 Ghz only AP on, SSID 5032, WPA3/SAE set to xxxxxxxx

I can connect the laptop via wire and my phone via 6 Ghz to the router.

I connected to the VH109 radio by 2.4 after flipping the dip switch. The team is set to 5032, ssidSuffix=“”.  I have set the 6 Ghz key to the same key as I set on the router (xxxxxxxx).

I can connect to the router using my phone - but the robot radio doesn’t seem to want to connect.

Any ideas for me to try?

I have a copy of the vh109 status page I can show.

This should be possible right?

Thanks Chris

link_counts.title: Tenda AXE5700 Smart WiFi 6E Router, Tri-Band Gigabit Wireless Router for Home, Best WiFi Router for Gaming and VR, AX Router with 5 * 6dBi High-Gain Antennas, Support WPA3, VPN, New 6GHz Band(RX27Pro) : Amazon.ca: Electronics

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked: I don’t really think that is possible, and you should return the router. The VH-109 is designed to use two radios, for best performance and reliability. In the meantime, until you can purchase another radio, you can try and use 2.4ghz, but the performance is not good.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
The external AP should be setup to act as an access point, not a router.

Set the external AP’s IP address to 10.TE. AM .4

Make sure the external AP is set to use a 6GHz channel in the 1-77 range.

Make sure the VH-109 is configured in ROBOT RADIO (Client) mode.

Configure the external AP SSID as your team number and with a WPA key.

Make sure the VH-109 is configured with your team number

Configure the VH-109 with the same WPA key you configured for the external AP’s SSID.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Chris (Mentor|5032)
posts.cooked:
Switched it to AP mode, set the ip on the router to 10.50.32.4.

For the 6 Wifi Ghz settings I have

Mode 802.11ax Security WPA3-SAE Channel 53 - Disabled PSC (Preferred scanning channel) Bandwidth 20

Firmware on the radio is 1.3.0 - should have mentioned that before.

Still doesnt want to connect.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Thermo:

Switched it to router mode, set the ip on the router to 10.50.32.4.

FletcherS7:

The external AP should be setup to act as an access point, not a router.

No wonder it’s not working.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
Thermo:

Bandwidth 20/40/80/160 Mhz Current bandwidth is 160

I don’t know for a fact if the VH-109 supports 160 MHz and 320 MHz I would recommend forcing it 20 MHz.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Chris (Mentor|5032)
posts.cooked:
Just tried forcing it to 20 and rebooted the robot.  Still doesn’t seem to connect. My phone does though.

I think I will leave it in the warehouse here in the dark to ponder life and see if I can figure out what I’m doing wrong Monday. Maybe it will realize it needs to make better choices.

Thanks for the quick responses!

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked:
I know it works for EERO 6E.  I’ll get my configuration this weekend and will post for you.

( Amazon eero Pro 6E tri-band mesh Wi-Fi 6E router, with built-in Zigbee smart home hub )

link_counts.title: Amazon eero Pro 6E tri-band mesh Wi-Fi 6E router, with built-in Zigbee smart home hub

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: think outside of the box from time to time

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked:
From what I can remember off the top of my head (this was done back in March):

If you were to set your router to 10.50.0.0 with netmask of 255.255.0.0.  Open it up, remember there are the top and bottom IP the radio need for itself so by putting the VH109 right in the middle you can get away with doing this.  Nice thing is that now you can connect your router to the Internet and if you run your laptop right off that router, you can be connected to both your Robot and the Internet at the same time.

The only gotcha with this is that you can only connected 1 robot to this at a time unless your router will allow you to create virtual AP on top (if you run it on your own Linux stack you probably can get away with doing that…been too long for me).

Ohh, of course all these does require that you don’t have anything upstream or you are directly connected to that is also in the 10.50.x.x range. If you do probably will need to NAT your router to something else first [I like to be on both robot and internet at the same time no need to keep switching network on the programming laptop].

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: think outside of the box from time to time

posts.name: Chris (Mentor|5032)
posts.cooked:
Ok, I finally got this working. After 2 days I decided the problem was the router. Sent that Tenda one back and purchased an eero Pro 6E per recommendation above.

Set it up as follows below and it connected immediately. Laptop connects via 5 Ghz to the same point and can browse internet and control the robot.

So it seems that there are issues with some routers sold as 6E routers.

Strange thing though - when I turn it on the blue 6 Ghz radio flashes - then goes out - and never lights back up again once it’s connected. Not sure if that’s normal.

Big Thanks to tkchan & FletcherS7

Chris

Settings in the eero app Plugged into home network, working in router mode SSID: 5032 SSID Key: xxxxxxxx 2.4 Ghz, 5 Ghz, and 6 Ghz Enabled DHCP & NAT Setting Manual IP IP Address prefix 10.0.0.0/8 Lease Range: Subnet IP: 10.50.0.0 Subnet Mask: 255.255.0.0 Starting IP: 10.50.32.100 Ending   IP: 10.50.32.150
